author: MarketBeat
title: Fresnillo (OTCMKTS:FNLPF) Reaches New 1-Year High - Still a Buy?
text:
Fresnillo (OTCMKTS:FNLPF) Reaches New 1-Year High - Still a Buy? Written by MarketBeat October 17, 2024 Share Link copied to clipboard. Fresnillo plc ( OTCMKTS:FNLPF - Get Free Report ) shares reached a new 52-week high during trading on Thursday . The stock traded as high as $8.95 and last traded at $8.95, with a volume of 5324 shares changing hands. The stock had previously closed at $8.72. Get Fresnillo alerts: Sign Up Analyst Upgrades and Downgrades
FNLPF has been the topic of several analyst reports. Berenberg Bank upgraded shares of Fresnillo from a "strong sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Friday, July 26th. Canaccord Genuity Group upgraded shares of Fresnillo to a "strong-buy" rating in a research report on Thursday, August 8th.
Read Our Latest Stock Analysis on FNLPF Fresnillo Stock Performance
The business's 50 day moving average price is $7.57 and its 200-day moving average price is $7.45. Fresnillo Company Profile ( Get Free Report )
Fresnillo plc mines, develops, and produces non-ferrous minerals in Mexico. It operates through seven segments: Fresnillo, Saucito, Ciénega, Herradura, Noche Buena, San Julián, and Juanicipio. The company primarily explores for silver, gold, lead, and zinc concentrates. Its projects include the Fresnillo silver mine located in the state of Zacatecas; Saucito silver mine situated in the state of Zacatecas; Ciénega gold mine located in the state of Durango; Herradura gold mine situated in the state of Sonora; Noche Buena gold mine located in the state of Sonora; San Julián silver-gold mine situated on the border of Chihuahua/Durango states; and Juanicipio mine located in the state of Zacatecas. author: @Jingya Jingya Huang
title: Supported models
text:
Trying to compile a transformers model I’m using Getting
KeyError: "hyenadna is not supported yet for transformers. Only ['...'] are supported for the library transformers. If you want to support hyenadna please propose a PR or open up an issue."
how/who decides which new models will be supported ?
Hi @ES-CONVERGE, what is the command/script you used to perform this conversion?
@ES-CONVERGE hyenadna uses remote code, it should be compatible with the APIs in Optimum in general, but as it’s not native citizen in the Transformers libraries. The best approach IMO would be creating a custom backend config and register it to the task manager of Optimum. WDYT @regisss?

author: WDAM Staff
title: $2.7 million grant to help AAA Ambulance upgrade fleet
text:
$2.7 million grant to help AAA Ambulance upgrade fleet
From Forrest Health System
PINE BELT, Miss. (WDAM) - A federal grant will help AAA Ambulance Service upgrade its fleet of vehicles as well as purchase more than two dozen, mechanical, chest-compression devices.
AAA Chief Executive Officer Chuck Carter said a $2.7 million Community Project Funding/Congressional Directed Spending grant, was sponsored by United States Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith (R-Miss.),
The CDS program allows members of Congress to request federal funds be set aside for specific projects in their states.
“We appreciate Sen. Hyde-Smith’s commitment to the people of South Mississippi in helping provide funding for this new equipment through a CDS grant,” Carter said. “This will help ensure that the patients we serve throughout our coverage area are receiving the best possible care.”
The grant will fund 27 “Lucas” devices, mechanical chest compression devices, which will be spread across the ambulance service’s coverage area.
The grant also will allow the purchase of 11, new ambulances, each with a “Power-LOAD” stretcher system.
Seven of the ambulances have arrived, and four more are in the final stages of completion at the vendor where lettering is being added and the Power-LOAD systems are being installed.
“Paired with the new ambulances, the LUCAS device and Power-LOAD system will help improve operational efficiency and safety,” Carter said.
The Power-LOAD stretcher system removes the problem of paramedics and emergency medical technicians having to lift patients multiple times when they go on a call, Carter said.
“The only lifting they will have to do is when they move the patient to or from the stretcher,” he said. “This protects both the patient and our personnel.”
The Lucas device is an automated, chest-compression system that is referred to as “your partner in life support,” Carter said.
The device, which is positioned both under and over a patient who is in cardiac arrest, performs chest compressions in place of an actual person, delivering guideline-consistent chest compressions to sudden cardiac arrest patients. The device can be used in the field, on the move and in the hospital.
The Lucas device is for use as a supplement to manual Cardiopulmonary resuscitation when effective manual CPR is not possible, like during transport, extended CPR, fatigue or when there is limited personnel.
Every online AAA Ambulance is equipped with the device.
Hyde-Smith said the AAA project is exactly what Congress had in mind when CDS was created.
“My goal as a senator is to work to responsibly (and) use the federal appropriations process to help Mississippi communities and organizations access resources that will help them best serve their residents,” Hyde-Smith said. “The funding for these new ambulances and equipment reflect that process, which will mean better emergency care for people in Hattiesburg and the Pine Belt.”
Founded in 1965, AAA Ambulance is Mississippi’s first and longest-standing emergency medical services provider. AAA was the first to be licensed, provide air response, train and test paramedics and to offer SMART 911.
AAA Ambulance Service has a staff of more than 300 people and covers Forrest, Perry, Pearl River, Marion, Jefferson Davis, Walthall and Pike counties, as well Hattiesburg city limits encased in Lamar County.
AAA’s communications center dispatches an average of 180 ground ambulance calls on a daily basis, as well as calls for three helicopters through Southeast Mississippi Air Ambulance District.

author: @bogota
title: Comité Distrital de Libertad Religiosa eligió su nueva junta directiva | Bogota.gov.co
text: En la primera sesión ordinaria de 2024, el Comité Distrital de Libertad Religiosa ha elegido su nueva Junta Directiva, liderada por Luis Andrés Montaño de Asoemprendedores como presidente. El pastor Jaime Zuluaga de la Iglesia Cristiana Ministerio Vida, MIV, y Antonio Lara de la Iglesia Evangélica Luterana de Colombia, Ielco, ocuparán los cargos de primer y segundo vicepresidente, respectivamente. Estos liderazgos religiosos, seleccionados democráticamente por representantes de diversas confesiones, dirigirán la corporación durante los próximos dos años. El Comité establecido mediante el Acuerdo 685 de 2017, supervisa y participa en la implementación de planes y estrategias para salvaguardar el derecho constitucional a profesar una fe, según lo establecido en el artículo 19 de la Constitución Política y en la Ley 133 de 1994. Julián Carvajal Zamora, subdirector de Asuntos de Libertad Religiosa, Cultos y Conciencia de la Secretaría de Gobierno, enfatizó en la importancia del sector religioso como aliado en la labor del Distrito y se comprometió a destacar su contribución social. Contenidos relacionados Además de la elección de la Junta Directiva, José Luis Caro Villafañe de la Iglesia Ministerio Internacional Tierra Prometida, fue seleccionado como delegado del Comité al Consejo Territorial de Planeación, mientras que José Albeiro Vergara de la Iglesia Centro Cristiano Misión Proyecto Fares y Francisco Javier López de la Iglesia Cristiana Salvación a las Naciones representarán al sector en el Consejo Distrital de Política Social. Lucio Chicunque Sánchez de la Iglesia Cristiana Integral La Fortaleza Shekinak y Caleb Delgadillo de la Iglesia Centro de Vida para las Familias, fueron designados como delegado y representante ante el Consejo Distrital de Protección a las Víctimas de Violencia Intrafamiliar y el Consejo Distrital de Paz, respectivamente.

author: STAFF REPORTS
title: chevron-right
text: JACKSON COUNTY, W.Va. (WCHS) — A Jackson County, West Virginia, teacher’s aide was charged after she was accused of dragging a young student across a floor and using excessive force, court records said. Nicole Lea Lupardus, 43, is charged with battery after an incident Monday, April 15, at Ripley Elementary Learning Center, according to a criminal complaint filed in Jackson County Magistrate Court. Lupardus is accused of dragging a 5-year-old student across the floor and physically picking them up and putting them in a seat. She is also accused of physically pushing the child against a table. The alleged incidents were recorded on surveillance video, the complaint said. Officers said they learned of the alleged incident after multiple faculty members contacted the county’s Shield Program coordinator. [The program was launched in 2022](https://wchstv.com/news/crisis-in-the-classroom/jackson-county-making-safety-a-priority-in-schools-through-new-program#) as an attempt to increase safety in schools. Witnesses told investigators they believed the incident could have injured the child. The child’s parents did not report any injuries, the complaint said.

author: Mathew Chaves
title: Amazon, P&G y Securitas entre las empresas que buscarán talento en masiva feria de empleo en Heredia
text: La búsqueda de talento en áreas de alta demanda como tecnología, servicios e ingeniería continúa siendo una prioridad para las empresas que operan en Costa Rica y las ferias de empleo presenciales se consolidan como un punto de encuentro entre las compañías y los profesionales que buscan nuevas oportunidades.

author: Hailey Morgan
title: Longtime Dismas of Vermont leader announces retirement
text: BURLINGTON, Vt. (WCAX) - A local organization that helps people get out of jail to build a life for themselves is celebrating the retirement of their longtime director. After nearly 40 years, Dismas of Vermont is saying farewell to Richard Gagne, one of its founding leaders. “The thing that really attracted me to Dismas was that what it was trying to accomplish here was a healing of that brokenness,” Gagne said. Gagne says he came to Burlington in search of a new purpose after working at a homeless shelter in Manchester, New Hampshire. He had been in the military, taught math to high school students, and been a part of a monastery. He wanted to make a difference in peoples’ lives and in 1986 thought Dismas House was a good start. “It makes me feel lucky. That’s the bottom line for me. I feel like it’s been a privilege. I feel like I got to do something that was meaningful to me and brought me happiness,” he said. Gagne has been there ever since, providing transitional housing for formerly incarcerated people. He invites volunteers to cook family meals with people living in the house, one of five in Vermont. He estimates that about 2,000 people have been integrated back into society during that time. And he’s helped many through the transition, including Justin Adair, who now works for the organization. “I don’t know what I would have done. Would I have stayed home? Would I have been surrounded by the same people I was surrounded by beforehand? Would I have fallen as a result of that? Would I have gotten myself into more trouble? I have no idea. I can tell you I’m glad that I did come and developed relationships with Kim and Richard,” Adair said. Gagne is now focused on finding a suitable replacement to fill his shoes. He says he’s going to spend his retirement building furniture and sculpting. He says he’s grateful for the journey he’s had. “I am lucky because I know that not everybody is not that lucky. But I was,” he said. Gagne will be honored as part of a Vermont Dismas Community Celebration on Saturday, May 4 at the Elley Long Center in Colchester at 6:30 p.m. Copyright 2024 WCAX. All rights reserved.

author: @PublimetroMX
title: Actor del Chavo del 8 sufre la pérdida de un ser querido
text:
El Chavo del 8 es una de las series de televisión más queridas y recordadas en el mundo hispano. Creada y protagonizada por Roberto Gómez Bolaños, esta comedia mexicana ha trascendido generaciones y fronteras, conquistando el corazón de millones de espectadores.
Algunas personas aseguran que el éxito del Chavo del 8 radica en su humor blanco y su capacidad para tocar temas universales como la amistad, la solidaridad, la pobreza y la inocencia. A través de personajes entrañables y situaciones cotidianas, la serie logra conectar con el público de todas las edades, transmitiendo valores positivos y dejando un mensaje de esperanza y optimismo.
Entre todos los personajes, Édgar Vivar, actor y comediante, se ganó el cariño de los televidentes tras interpretar a dos personajes icónicos: El Señor Barriga y Ñoño. Desafortunadamente, Édgar anunció en su cuenta de X el fallecimiento de su madre.
Con un simple, pero sincero texto, el comediante se despidió de su mamá: “Mamita linda, te mudaste a mi corazón. El Creador te recibe con los brazos abiertos”. Asimismo, Vivar compartió una foto en la que se le ve junto a su progenitora.
Édgar Vivar nació el 28 de diciembre de 1948 en la Ciudad de México. Desde joven mostró interés por las artes, pero inicialmente se inclinó por la medicina, llegando a estudiar esta carrera. Sin embargo, su pasión por la actuación lo llevó a cambiar de rumbo y a dedicarse por completo al mundo del espectáculo.
La gran oportunidad de Édgar Vivar llegó en 1973, cuando se unió al elenco de “El Chavo del 8″, una serie creada y protagonizada por Roberto Gómez Bolaños, conocido como “Chespirito”. En esta producción, Vivar interpretó a los personajes antes dichos.

author: Ashley Chan
title: Blood Cancer Trial Resumes Enrollment, Shows Improved Ewing Sarcoma Results
text: A phase 1/2 trial evaluating seclidemstat plus Vidaza resumed patient enrollment for those with certain blood cancers and another phase 1/2 trial demonstrated improved results in patients with Ewing sarcomas. A phase 1/2 trial evaluating the treatment combination of seclidemstat and Vidaza (azacytidine) has resumed patient enrollment for those with some blood cancers, according to biopharmaceutical company Salarius Pharmaceuticals, the manufacturer of seclidemstat. Seclidemstat is a novel oral drug that helps prevent the growth of cancer cells by blocking certain enzymes that are essential for cell growth. Vidaza is a drug that may help prevent some growth that may become cancer. The combination of these two drugs may increase the likelihood of destroying more cancer cells, according to the National Cancer Institute. In particular, a news release from Salarius Pharmaceuticals reported that the treatment combination of seclidemstat and Vidaza would be evaluated to treat patients with myelodysplastic syndrome (MSD) and chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML), a rare form of blood cancer. The respective phase 1/2 trial’s primary objectives include determining the safety and tolerability of the drug combination, as well as establishing the maximum dose that can be tolerated by patients. The researchers also aim to evaluate the overall response rate (ORR; percentage of patients who have a partial or complete response to treatment) after receiving the drug combination, ClinicalTrial.gov stated on the trial’s listing. Secondary objectives for the trial also include analyzing the overall survival (OS; length of time from diagnosis or the start of treatment when a patient is still alive) and duration of response (DOR; length of time when a tumor continues responding to treatment without growth). Other secondary objectives in the trial are relapse-free survival (RFS; length of time after primary treatment when a patient lives without signs of cancer), leukemia-free survival and safety. According to the same listing from ClinicalTrials.gov, the estimated enrollment is expected to be 44 patients with either MDS or CMML. The estimated date of completion for the study is September 2025. The trial, being conducted at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, was put on a partial pause by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in October 2022 after there was a suspected unexpected serious side effect, according to the news release. More specifically, the news release stated that the serious side effect was observed only in patients with FET-rearranged sarcoma who were receiving seclidemstat. “We are pleased that the FDA has removed the partial clinical hold on the MD Anderson trial with seclidemstat in blood cancers, and we are excited about the prospect of MD Anderson enrolling additional patients and building a broader database of patient data,” David Arthur, president and chief executive officer of Salarius Pharmaceuticals, said in the news release. “(MD Anderson Cancer Center) researchers previously reported what we believe are encouraging interim results, and we look forward to learning what potential benefits patients will experience at higher doses of seclidemstat.” Another phase 1/2 trial from Salarius analyzing seclidemstat in approximately 50 patients with Ewing sarcomas, a type of cancer occurring in the bones and soft tissue, reported that a patient demonstrated a partial response after receiving a treatment combination of Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide) and Hycamtin (topotecan) according to the ClinicalTrials.gov listing. The news release noted that the partial response to treatment has led to a 60% objective response rate (percentage of patients who have a partial or complete response to treatment) and a 60% disease control rate (percentage of patients with a partial or complete response, or stable disease after treatment). “We are also pleased to see that patients continuing treatment with seclidemstat and (Cytoxan and Hycamtin) continue to improve. With our Food and Drug Administration Type B meeting process completed, we plan to file an amended Ewing protocol focusing on first relapse patients, who we believe will benefit from Seclidemstat and (Cytoxan and Hycamtin) combination therapy,“ Arthur added. For more news on cancer updates, research and education, don’t forget to [subscribe to CURE®’s newsletters here](https://www.curetoday.com/view/enews?tfa_2=CUREARTICLE&utm_source=form&utm_medium=article&utm_campaign=footer).
